head.title: Perovskite Light-Emitting Diodes via Laser Crystallization: Systematic Investigation on Grain Size Effects for Device Performance | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Perovskite Light-Emitting Diodes via Laser Crystallization: Systematic Investigation on Grain Size Effects for Device Performance

Owing to unique potential for high color purity luminance based on low-cost solution processes, organic/inorganic hybrid perovskite light-emitting diodes (PeLEDs) are attracting a great deal of research attention. For high performance PeLEDs, optimum control of the perovskite film morphology is a critical parameter. Here, we introduce a reliable and well-controllable PeLED crystallization process based on beam-damage-free near-infrared laser (λ = 808 nm) irradiation. Morphology of the CH3NH3PbBr3 films can be precisely controlled by laser irradiation condition parameters: power density and beam scan rate. We systematically investigate the perovskite film morphology and device performance of the PeLEDs under different processing conditions. In the optimum power density and high beam scan rate (30 W cm–2, 0.1 mm s–1), a dense and smooth perovskite film is attained with a small crystal grain size. The critical relationship between the crystal grain size and LED efficiency is established while attaining the device performance of 0.95 cd A–1 efficiency and 1784 cd m–2.

div.p:
Owing to unique potential for high color purity luminance based on low-cost solution processes, organic/inorganic hybrid perovskite light-emitting diodes (PeLEDs) are attracting a great deal of research attention. For high performance PeLEDs, optimum control of the perovskite film morphology is a critical parameter. Here, we introduce a reliable and well-controllable PeLED crystallization process based on beam-damage-free near-infrared laser (λ = 808 nm) irradiation. Morphology of the CH
3
NH
3
PbBr
3
films can be precisely controlled by laser irradiation condition parameters: power density and beam scan rate. We systematically investigate the perovskite film morphology and device performance of the PeLEDs under different processing conditions. In the optimum power density and high beam scan rate (30 W cm
–2
, 0.1 mm s
–1
), a dense and smooth perovskite film is attained with a small crystal grain size. The critical relationship between the crystal grain size and LED efficiency is established while attaining the device performance of 0.95 cd A
–1
efficiency and 1784 cd m
–2
.

div.div:
Recent emergence of organic/inorganic hybrid perovskites opens up unprecedented opportunities for optoelectronics. Synergistic combination of organic and inorganic components shares the contradictory benefits of two different components; organic components allow for facile solution processing at a low temperature and flexible mechanical property, whereas inorganic counterparts facilitate superior electrical properties including charge carrier density, mobility, and so on. As such, hybrid perovskites hold great promise for light-harvesting/-emitting applications including solar cells, light-emitting diodes (LEDs), photodetectors, and laser.
(1-7)
For light-emitting applications, more specifically, hybrid perovskites particularly show latent possibilities, such as high color purity, easy control of the color spectrum, quantum well band structure formation, and low-cost scalable solution processing. Current research efforts are focusing on how to enhance luminescence efficiency by balancing charge transport and injection, minimizing nonradiative recombination,
(8-10)
synthesis of nanoparticles and their applications,
(11-17)
restructuring dimensionality of perovskites,
(18-23)
and so on for the realization of practically meaningful device performance.

Morphology and crystal grain size of hybrid perovskite layers are known to be broadly tunable by various processing parameters. Ideal perovskite light-emitting layers should have minimal defects, a uniform thickness, and a smooth film surface to avoid exciton quenching, nonradiative recombination, and current leakage. In this respect, widely used 3-dimensional (3D) hybrid perovskites reveal intrinsic limitations, principally associated with the low exciton binding energy (9–60 meV) and long exciton diffusion length. Alternatively, physical confinement of excitons proposes a promising route to high efficiency LEDs. It has been reported that the smaller the size of crystal grains, the higher the exciton binding energy.
(24)
A lot of interesting attempts including spatial confinement via ultra-thin film formation and nanoscale crystal pinning
(25)
have been explored with high current efficiency outcomes. Nonetheless, it is still unclear whether the small grain size is indeed useful for radiative decay, as the number of grain boundary may also play the role of quenching sites.

In this work, we demonstrate precisely controllable crystallization of all-solution processed organic/inorganic hybrid perovskite LEDs (PeLEDs) by means of beam-damage-free near-infrared diode laser. Laser crystallization is a convincing method for material processing owing to its intrinsic competitiveness such as rapid heating and cooling, room temperature continuous processing, intrinsic compatibility with flexible device geometry, process scalability, and area selectivity.
(26)
We employed direct irradiation of the laser beam (wavelength: 808 nm) onto a CH
3
NH
3
PbBr
3
(MAPbBr
3
) perovskite precursor layer formed on poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):polystyrene sulfonate (PEDOT:PSS)-coated indium tin oxide (ITO). Notably, uniform grain sizes of perovskite crystallites are attained over a large area in a reliable way such that effects from the small crystalline grain size on the luminescence behavior could be systematically investigated.

Figure 1
a schematically illustrates the laser crystallization of the MAPbBr
3
perovskite light-emitting layer deposited by the single step solution process. Perovskite precursor solution including methylammonium bromide and lead(II) bromide is spin-coated onto glass/ITO/PEDOT:PSS substrates under the dripping of the chlorobenzene/chloroform mixture solvent (v/v = 5:5). Diode laser with an 808 nm wavelength is laterally scanned on the as-cast film surface while varying the laser power density and scan rate. Poorly crystalline as-deposited films transform into a well-defined polycrystalline morphology by the laser irradiation due to the instantaneous photothermal heating process. The resultant morphology of perovskite strongly depends on the laser irradiation parameters such as power density and scan rate. It is noteworthy that photothermal conversion of laser beam principally occurs at PEDOT:PSS and ITO layers.
(26-28)
Thus, the thickness and chemical composition of those bottom layers also significantly influence the photothermal heating process to attain different annealing temperatures.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Schematic illustration of the laser-crystallization process. There is no difference between before and after laser crystallization except the grain size and morphology. (b) SEM images of the MAPbBr
3
film morphology controlled by laser power density (fixed scan rate: 0.1 mm s
–1
). The MAPbBr
3
precursor layer is exposed to laser beam with various power densities from 20 to 50 W cm
–2
. The tendency of the grain size is scaled with increased power density. However, a discrete cuboid grain and discontinuous morphology appeared in 20 W cm
–2
condition. (c) Cross-sectional SEM images of laser-crystallized MAPbBr
3
with irradiated laser power density. As the power density increases, grain tends to be a well-defined increased grain size while maintaining the film thickness (about 200 nm) and morphology. In addition, 50 W cm
–2
power density induces nonuniformity of the MAPbBr
3
thin film.

div.div:
Figure 1
b,c compares the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the perovskite films crystallized by laser power densities from 20 to 50 W cm
–2
with a fixed scan rate of 0.1 mm s
–1
(
Figure 1
b). In general, the higher the laser power density and the slower the scan rate, the larger grains of perovskites with less grain boundaries. However, the highest power density around 40–50 W cm
–2
causes a nonuniform film morphology with a roughened film surface. By contrast, the lowest power density of 20 W cm
–2
results in a nonuniform and porous morphology with relatively small grains because of the insufficient laser power density regardless of the scan rate. An insufficient power density yields small size grains with abundant grain boundaries both in horizontal and vertical directions to the film plane. The average grain size is typically controllable from 40 to 300 nm along with the laser power density (
Table S1
).

We could directly monitor the morphology evolution of the MAPbBr
3
perovskite film upon the photothermal heating process (
Figure 2
). Before laser irradiation, the as-cast perovskite layer exhibits a quenched thin film morphology including small particles with low crystallinity. Along the advance of the bottom stage at a fixed rate, the target area of the perovskite film approaches the laser irradiation area. As soon as the laser beam is irradiated, the perovskite particles start to aggregate with the temperature rise induced by photothermal heating. After passing through the intensity peak area, the perovskite film starts to cool down. The aggregated particles gradually transform into crystal grains. The crystallization nucleates from the bottom interface with the PEDOT:PSS layer (photothermal conversion layer), propagates along the film thickness direction, and eventually reaches the top surface of the perovskite layer. Finally, this grain growth along the film thickness yields thick crystal grains extending over the entire film thickness. It is noticeable that the grain boundary is formed only in the vertical direction without any grain boundary oriented in the film plane direction.

div.p:
Figure 2. SEM images of the MAPbBr
3
morphology of the grain growth procedure during laser irradiation controlled by irradiation conditions (scale bar: 500 nm). The inset figures show sequence of a grain boundary formation from (a) morphology quenching to perovskite particles, (b) aggregation of particles, and then (c, d) the grain and grain boundary growth. Final (e) grain size distribution is determined by total thermal energy, that is, power density of laser beam.

div.div:
Optoelectronic performance of the laser-crystallized MAPbBr
3
PeLEDs was investigated.
Figure 3
a shows the current efficiency measured at various laser power densities from 20 to 50 W cm
–2
with scan rates from 0.05 to 0.5 mm s
–1
. It is evident that a high power density requires a relatively fast scan rate for a uniform film morphology, suggesting that there is an optimal combination of power density and scan rate for a desired film morphology. The morphological variation presented in
Figure 1
directly correlates with the device performance.
Figure 3
b–d exhibits the variations of current density, luminance, and current efficiency characteristics as a function of operating voltage of PeLEDs for various laser power densities (at a fixed scan rate of 0.1 mm s
–1
). In our experiment, the PeLED fabricated by power density of 30 W cm
–2
with scan rate of 0.1 mm s
–1
presents the best efficiency and luminance. This result is also better than the PeLED fabricated by the conventional thermal annealing process (100 °C, 10 min,
Figure S1
). Current efficiency of PeLEDs varies consistently with luminance along with laser power density. PeLED fabricated by 30 W cm
–2
shows the highest luminance for the entire voltage range. Laser power density above 40 W cm
–2
induces a significant decrease in luminance. Optoelectronic performance of PeLEDs with other scan rates, 0.5 and 0.05 mm s
–1
, are summarized in
Figures S2 & S3
, respectively.

div.p:
Figure 3. Optoelectronic characteristics of PeLEDs. (a) Statistical data of current efficiencies with coincidence laser power density. (b) Current density, (c) luminance, and (d) current efficiency of PeLED based on the laser-crystallization processed MAPbBr
3
layer with various laser irradiation conditions (fixed scan rate: 0.1 mm s
–1
).

div.div:
Interestingly, the variation of current efficiency is consistent with the variation of grain size along with laser power density.
Figure 4
a shows the variation of current efficiency plotted against the crystal grain size. Black squares indicate the experimental data and the red solid line represents the interpolated trend line. It reveals that the PeLEDs with smaller grain sizes demonstrate higher current efficiency.
Figure 4
b summarizes the grain size of MAPbBr
3
as a function of laser power density. Initially, laser crystallization with 20 W cm
–2
yields an average grain size of 50 nm, whereas that with 30 W cm
–2
produces the smallest average grain size of 45 nm and further increase results in the hundreds of nanometer size grains with a large standard deviation.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Fitting analysis of perovskite LEDs’ current efficiency and MAPbBr
3
perovskite grain size. (b) Correlation curve of MAPbBr
3
perovskite grain size distribution with power density. Current efficiency of PeLED strongly depends on perovskite grain size distribution. The perovskite LED which has a smaller grain size shows higher current efficiency. (c) XRD spectrum exhibit clearly peaks that can be assigned to (100), (110), (200), (210), (211), (220), and (300) planes, respectively. There is no difference of characteristics XRD peak position of MAPbBr
3
perovskite films with irradiated laser power density (scan rate, 0.1 mm s
–1
). (d) UV–visible spectrum of MAPbBr
3
with irradiated laser power density at constant scan rate, 0.1 mm s
–1
. UV absorption peak and photoluminescence peak are matched at 531 nm. There are no compositional changes by laser power even 50 W cm
–2
.

div.div:
The crystal structures of MAPbBr
3
films irradiated with different laser power densities are analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (
Figure 4
c). All XRD patterns show sharp diffraction peaks at 14.94°, 30.14°, and 45.88° for the (100), (200), and (300) lattice planes of the perovskite crystal, respectively.
(29)
The peak positions and intensities do not significantly vary with the laser crystallization condition.
Figure 4
d shows UV–vis absorbance measured for the analysis of compositional and dimensional variation of the perovskite layer with respect to the laser beam power density from 20 to 50 W cm
–2
with a fixed scan rate of 0.1 mm s
–1
. UV absorption peak is broadly detected near 520 nm and all spectra show similar absorbance behavior even at the highest power density of 50 W cm
–2
, indicating that the variation of laser power density does not influence the chemical composition of perovskite crystals. This confirms that laser crystallization condition does not significantly influence on the genuine crystal structure and the corresponding energy band structure, but principally on the crystal grain growth.

The luminescent properties of MAPbBr
3
films were investigated by steady-state photoluminescence (PL) measurements (
Figure 5
a). The position of the PL peak (530 nm) does not depend on the power density of laser irradiation. By contrast, the power density induces the variation of PL intensity, where 30 W cm
–2
showed the highest intensity. This is due to the smallest average grain size and smooth and continuous film morphology. Notably, it has been reported that the perovskite film with the small grain size can produce highly confined excitons and reduces exciton quenching.
(25)
Overall, the high current efficiency of PeLEDs is attributed to the synergetic effects from exciton confinement and efficient electron injection mediated by the grain size.

div.p:
Figure 5. (a) PL measurement data of perovskite films with different laser irradiation conditions. Each film was irradiated with different laser powers with 0.1 mm s
–1
scan rate. The PL data showed similar tendency with maximum current efficiency of LED devices. (b) TRPL measurement of each perovskite film with different laser irradiation conditions. Each film shows biexponential decay curve. The shorter component is originated from nonradiative recombination, and the longer component is originated from radiative recombination. From this data, 30 W cm
–2
laser irradiation with 0.1 mm s
–1
scan rate showed the fastest radiative recombination, which showed the same tendency of current efficiency data.

div.div:
Additionally, time-resolved PL (TRPL) was also measured with the same set of samples (
Figure 5
b). All films showed biexponential decay curves. The shorter component is originated by trap-assisted nonradiative recombination, and the longer component is originated by radiative recombination (
Table 1
).
(30)
From the radiative recombination component, 30 W cm
–2
laser irradiation showed the shortest lifetime, signifying that excitons in this film can easily undergo radiative recombination. Overall, this could lead to the highly efficient LED devices with 30 W cm
–2
laser irradiation.
Table 1. TRPL Measurement Decay Data of Each Film

We have presented a well-controlled crystallization strategy based on laser irradiation for high performance perovskite solar cells and PeLEDs.
(26)
Currently, thermal treatment is the most popular method to convert solution-processed precursor films into the perovskite phase, where different processing parameters commonly lead to the uncontrolled alternation of surface coverage, grain size, and relevant material properties. In particular, the relationship between the grain size and device performance is one of the most important issues
(25, 31)
because small grains can confine the excitons but also generate defects. Our result supports that the small grain size can enhance the luminance and efficiency of PeLEDs, but further accumulation of systematic studies is required to clarify the relationship between the grain size and device performance.

In this study, we concluded a noticeable improvement of all-solution processed PeLED’s efficiency, 0.95 cd A
–1
with the defect-free glossy light-emitting layer and several dozen nanosized gain distribution attained via well-controlled laser beam crystallization. Furthermore, from the steady-state PL and TRPL measurements, we reasoned the luminance and current efficiency enhancement of perovskite LEDs. While our method presents overall device efficiency relatively lower than those of the state of the art level performances reported nowadays, our systematic investigation offers a valuable opportunity for the scientific understanding of crystallization-device performance relationship for PeLEDs based on all solution process device structures with easily controllable grain size and high speed continuous process. Moreover, as research demand for the commercialization of perovskite optoelectronics is rapidly growing, reliable large-area film formation methods with high speed and process continuity are becoming more and more significant. A robust crystallization method relying on laser beam, also compatible to large area/flexible devices at low-temperature continuous processing, could be crucial for eventual practical success.

PEDOT:PSS were spin-coated on ITO at 4000 rpm for 30 s and annealed at 150 °C for 15 min. For perovskite layer formation, MAPbBr
3
precursor solution was prepared by dissolving methylammonium bromide and lead(II) bromide with 1:1 molar ratio in mixed solvent of γ-butyrolactone (from Sigma-Aldrich) and dimethylsulfoxide (from Sigma-Aldrich) with 7:3 volume ratio at room temperature. The MAPbBr
3
thin film was formed by the nonsolvent dripping process (named additive nanocrystal pinning) during the spin coating of precursor solution at 3000 rpm for 55 s in an N
2
-filled glovebox. Laser irradiation was carried out by using a diode laser source with an 808 nm wavelength line beam (
d
x
= 30 mm,
d
y
= 0.1 mm) near-IR diode laser (DILAS M1L-808.10 350C). Electron transport material, BCP solution with chlorobenzene, was spin-casted in the glovebox at 3000 rpm for 60 s without thermal annealing, respectively. Finally, LiF and aluminum electrodes were sequentially deposited by thermal evaporation. The active area of PeLEDs is 18 mm
2
(9 mm × 2 mm).

Morphology of the perovskite film layer and PeLEDs was characterized by SEM (S-4800, Hitachi). XRD patterns of perovskite thin films were obtained using Rigaku D/Max-2500 (Cu Kα radiation, 40 kV, 300 mA). PL spectra were characterized by using a time-correlated single-photon counting system (iHR320, HORIBA Jobin Yvon Inc.). The UV–vis absorption spectrum was measured with a UV–vis spectrometer (SolidSpec-3700, Shimadzu). The current–voltage–luminance characteristics and electroluminescence spectra were measured by using a Keithley 2400 source measurement and a SR-3A spectroradiometer from Topcon.

span.span: Crystal organometal halide perovskites with promising optoelectronic applications

div.div:

Crystal organometal halide perovskites with promising optoelectronic applications
Chen, Junnian; Zhou, Shasha; Jin, Shengye; Li, Huiqiao; Zhai, Tianyou
Journal of Materials Chemistry C: Materials for Optical and Electronic Devices
(
2016
),
4
(
1
),
11-27
CODEN:
JMCCCX
; ISSN:
2050-7534
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. Organometal halide perovskites AMX3 (A = org. cation, M = metal cation, and X = halogen anion) were dominating the photovoltaic fields with an unexpected sharp efficiency enhancement to 20.1% in the past 5 years. The extraordinary properties of optical absorption, luminescence and low nonradiative recombination rates extend their applications into optoelectronic fields beyond photovoltaic devices. This article briefly outlines the state-of-the-art research activities of crystal perovskite AMX3, describes the fundamental optoelectronic properties, specific morphols. and related synthesis techniques, and summarizes their functions in optoelectronic fields such as solar cells, lasers, light-emitting diodes and photodetectors. The general challenges and the potential future directions of this exciting research area are highlighted.

span.span: Perovskite Materials for Light-Emitting Diodes and Lasers

div.div:
[

],

Perovskite Materials for Light-Emitting Diodes and Lasers
Veldhuis, Sjoerd A.; Boix, Pablo P.; Yantara, Natalia; Li, Mingjie; Sum, Tze Chien; Mathews, Nripan; Mhaisalkar, Subodh G.
Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany)
(
2016
),
28
(
32
),
6804-6834
CODEN:
ADVMEW
; ISSN:
0935-9648
.
(
Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
)
Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites have cemented their position as an exceptional class of optoelectronic materials thanks to record photovoltaic efficiencies of 22.1%, as well as promising demonstrations of light-emitting diodes, lasers, and light-emitting transistors. Perovskite materials with photoluminescence quantum yields close to 100% and perovskite light-emitting diodes with external quantum efficiencies of 8% and current efficiencies of 43 cd A-1 have been achieved. Although perovskite light-emitting devices are yet to become industrially relevant, in merely two years these devices have achieved the brightness and efficiencies that org. light-emitting diodes accomplished in two decades. Further advances will rely decisively on the multitude of compositional, structural variants that enable the formation of lower-dimensionality layered and three-dimensional perovskites, nanostructures, charge-transport materials, and device processing with architectural innovations. Here, the rapid advancements in perovskite light-emitting devices and lasers are reviewed. The key challenges in materials development, device fabrication, operational stability are addressed, and an outlook is presented that will address market viability of perovskite light-emitting devices.

span.span: Planar heterojunction organometal halide perovskite solar cells: roles of interfacial layers

div.div:
[
Crossref
], [

],
Google Scholar
3
Planar heterojunction organometal halide perovskite solar cells: roles of interfacial layers
Kim, Hobeom; Lim, Kyung-Geun; Lee, Tae-Woo
Energy & Environmental Science
(
2016
),
9
(
1
),
12-30
CODEN:
EESNBY
; ISSN:
1754-5706
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Organometal halide perovskites are promising photo-absorption materials in solar cells due to their high extinction coeff., broad light absorption range and excellent semiconducting properties. The highest power conversion efficiency (PCE) of perovskite solar cells (PrSCs) is now 20.1%. However, a high-temp. processed mesoscopic metal oxide (e.g., TiO2) must be removed to realize flexible PrSCs on plastic substrates using low temp. processes. Although the planar heterojunction (PHJ) structure can be considered as the most appropriate structure for flexible PrSCs, they have shown lower PCEs than those with a mesoscopic metal oxide layer. Therefore, development of interfacial layers is essential for achieving highly efficient PHJ PrSCs, and necessary in fabrication of flexible PrSCs. This review article gives an overview of progress in PHJ PrSCs and the roles of interfacial layers in the device, and suggests a practical strategy to fabricate highly efficient and flexible PHJ PrSCs. We conclude with our tech. suggestion and outlook for further research direction.

This work proposes a new perovskite solar cell structure by including lithium-neutralized graphene oxide (GO-Li) as the electron transporting layer (ETL) on top of the mesoporous TiO2 (m-TiO2) substrate. The modified work-function of GO after the intercalation of Li atoms (4.3 eV) exhibits a good energy matching with the TiO2 conduction band, leading to a significant enhancement of the electron injection from the perovskite to the m-TiO2. The resulting devices exhibit an improved short circuit current and fill factor and a reduced hysteresis. Furthermore, the GO-Li ETL partially passivates the oxygen vacancies/defects of m-TiO2 by resulting in an enhanced stability under prolonged 1 SUN irradn.

Graphene Interface Engineering for Perovskite Solar Modules: 12.6% Power Conversion Efficiency over 50 cm2 Active Area
Agresti, Antonio; Pescetelli, Sara; Palma, Alessandro L.; Del Rio Castillo, Antonio E.; Konios, Dimitrios; Kakavelakis, George; Razza, Stefano; Cina, Lucio; Kymakis, Emmanuel; Bonaccorso, Francesco; Di Carlo, Aldo

Interfaces between perovskite solar cell (PSC) layer components play a pivotal role in obtaining high-performance premium cells and large-area modules. Graphene and related two-dimensional materials (GRMs) can be used to "on-demand" tune the interface properties of PSCs. We successfully used GRMs to realize large-area (active area 50.6 cm2) perovskite-based solar modules (PSMs), achieving a record high power conversion efficiency of 12.6%. We on-demand modulated the photoelectrode charge dynamic by doping the mesoporous TiO2 (mTiO2) layer with graphene flakes. Moreover, we exploited lithium-neutralized graphene oxide flakes as interlayer at the mTiO2/perovskite interface to improve charge injection. Notably, prolonged aging tests have shown the long-term stability for both small- and large-area devices using graphene-doped mTiO2. Furthermore, the possibility of producing and processing GRMs in the form of inks opens a promising route for further scale-up and stabilization of the PSM, the gateway for the commercialization of this technol.

Recent advances in plasmonic metal and rare-earth-element upconversion nanoparticle doped perovskite solar cells
Kakavelakis, G.; Petridis, K.; Kymakis, E.

A review. Org.-inorg. lead halide based perovskite solar cells are considered as one of the most promising 3rd generation photovoltaic technologies, since within a few years of focused research efforts, they have already presented certified efficiencies surpassing 22%. The high performance, together with the low fabrication cost, makes this technol. competitive with state-of-the-art thin film photovoltaics (CdTe and CIGS). However perovskite solar cells present some striking disadvantages hindering their commercialization, including a lower performance compared to com. available Si based photovoltaics (26.6%), a low stability tolerance under high levels of moisture and temp., lead B-cation toxicity and the hysteresis effect which ruins both the performance and long term stability of the devices. Recently, a promising approach to tackle the aforementioned disadvantages was the introduction of plasmonic metal and rare-earth-element upconversion nanoparticles in the building blocks of the devices. The authors review the theor. and exptl. results of the literature regarding the introduction of different constitution, size, shape and coating plasmonic metal and rare-earth-element upconversion nanoparticles into the building blocks of both planar and mesoscopic perovskite solar cells. The authors analyze their effect on the device performance, stability, hysteresis effect and how they can be very beneficial for making these solar cells environmentally friendly and compatible with tandem applications. The crit. challenges and the prospects of this newly developed field and propose some prospects for future research directions are discussed.

Bright light-emitting diodes based on organometal halide perovskite
Tan, Zhi-Kuang; Moghaddam, Reza Saberi; Lai, May Ling; Docampo, Pablo; Higler, Ruben; Deschler, Felix; Price, Michael; Sadhanala, Aditya; Pazos, Luis M.; Credgington, Dan; Hanusch, Fabian; Bein, Thomas; Snaith, Henry J.; Friend, Richard H.

Solid-state light-emitting devices based on direct-bandgap semiconductors have, over the past two decades, been utilized as energy-efficient sources of lighting. However, fabrication of these devices typically relies on expensive high-temp. and high-vacuum processes, rendering them uneconomical for use in large-area displays. Here, we report high-brightness light-emitting diodes based on soln.-processed organometal halide perovskites. We demonstrate electroluminescence in the near-IR, green and red by tuning the halide compns. in the perovskite. In our IR device, a thin 15 nm layer of CH3NH3PbI3-xClx perovskite emitter is sandwiched between larger-bandgap titanium dioxide (TiO2) and poly(9,9'-dioctylfluorene) (F8) layers, effectively confining electrons and holes in the perovskite layer for radiative recombination. We report an IR radiance of 13.2 W sr-1 m-2 at a c.d. of 363 mA cm-2, with highest external and internal quantum efficiencies of 0.76% and 3.4%, resp. In our green light-emitting device with an ITO/PEDOT:PSS/CH3NH3PbBr3/F8/Ca/Ag structure, we achieved a luminance of 364 cd m-2 at a c.d. of 123 mA cm-2, giving external and internal quantum efficiencies of 0.1% and 0.4%, resp. We show, using photoluminescence studies, that radiative bimol. recombination is dominant at higher excitation densities. Hence, the quantum efficiencies of the perovskite light-emitting diodes increase at higher current densities. This demonstration of effective perovskite electroluminescence offers scope for developing this unique class of materials into efficient and color-tunable light emitters for low-cost display, lighting and optical communication applications.

Electroluminescence in light-emitting devices relies on the encounter and radiative recombination of electrons and holes in the emissive layer. In organometal halide perovskite light-emitting diodes, poor film formation creates elec. shunting paths, where injected charge carriers bypass the perovskite emitter, leading to a loss in electroluminescence yield. Here, the authors report a soln.-processing method to block elec. shunts and thereby enhance electroluminescence quantum efficiency in perovskite devices. In this method, a blend of perovskite and a polyimide precursor dielec. (PIP) is soln.-deposited to form perovskite nanocrystals in a thin-film matrix of PIP. The PIP forms a pinhole-free charge-blocking layer, while still allowing the embedded perovskite crystals to form elec. contact with the electron- and hole-injection layers. This modified structure reduces nonradiative current losses and improves quantum efficiency by 2 orders of magnitude, giving an external quantum efficiency of 1.2%. This simple technique provides an alternative route to circumvent film formation problems in perovskite optoelectronics and offers the possibility of flexible and high-performance light-emitting displays.

Soln.-processable perovskite materials have garnered tremendous attention because of their excellent charge carrier mobility, possibility of a tunable optical bandgap, and high photoluminescence quantum efficiency (PLQE). In particular, the uniform morphol. of a perovskite film is the most important factor in realizing perovskite light-emitting diodes (PeLEDs) with high efficiency and full-coverage electroluminescence (EL). In this study, we demonstrate highly efficient PeLEDs that contain a perovskite film with a uniform morphol. by introducing HBr into the perovskite precursor. The introduction of HBr into the perovskite precursor results in a perovskite film with a uniform, continuous morphol. because the HBr increases the soly. of the inorg. component in the perovskite precursor and reduces the crystn. rate of the perovskite film upon spin-coating. Moreover, PeLEDs fabricated using perovskite films with a uniform, continuous morphol., which were deposited using 6 vol% HBr in a DMF (DMF)/hydrobromic acid (HBr) cosolvent, exhibited full coverage of the green EL emission. Finally, the optimized PeLEDs fabricated with perovskite films deposited using the DMF/HBr cosolvent exhibited a max. luminance of 3490 cd m-2 (at 4.3 V) and a luminous efficiency of 0.43 cd A-1 (at 4.3 V).

A facile synthetic method to produce highly emissive MeNH3+PbBr3- nanoplatelets with bright, stable, and spectrally narrow emission is presented. Compared to polycryst. bulk perovskites, the nanoplatelets have significantly higher PL quantum yield that allows for the fabrication of bright elec. driven PeLEDs. The high stability and moisture resistance of these org. ligand-capped perovskites nanoplatelets enables glove box-free device fabrication. The integration of bipolar PVK:PBD layer with the soln.-processable perovskite nanoplatelets layer improved the film morphol., as well as charge transport and recombination, resulting in 1 of the brightest perovskite LEDs reported to date. The work demonstrates a new pathway toward optoelectronic devices based on soln.-processable materials and further shows the promises of nanoscale org.-inorg. halide perovskites as a new class of semiconductors with desirable characteristics for optoelectronic devices. The demonstrated emitter/bipolar host structure can be extended, to other perovskite nanostructures as light emitter for optoelectronic. devices, and finally achieve the white light PeLED by using the mixt. of perovskite with different emission wavelengths.

Organometal halide perovskites quantum dots (OHP-QDs) with bright, color-tunable, and narrow-band photoluminescence have significant advantages in display, lighting, and laser applications. Due to sparse concns. and difficulties in the enrichment of OHP-QDs, prodn. of large-area uniform films of OHP-QDs is a challenging task, which largely impedes their use in electroluminescence devices. Here, a simple dip-coating method has been reported to effectively fabricate large-area uniform films of OHP-QDs. Using this technique, multicolor OHP-QDs light-emitting diodes (OQ-LEDs) emitting in blue, blue-green, green, orange, and red color have been successfully produced by simply tuning the halide compn. or size of QDs. The blue, green, and red OQ-LEDs exhibited, resp., a max. luminance of 2673, 2398, and 986 cd m-2 at a current efficiency of 4.01, 3.72, and 1.52 cd A-1, and an external quantum efficiency of 1.38%, 1.06%, and 0.53%, which are much better than most LEDs based on OHP films. The packaged OQ-LEDs show long-term stability in air (humidity ≈50%) for at least 7 d. The results demonstrate the great potential of the dip-coating method to fabricate large-area uniform films for various QDs. The high-efficiency OQ-LEDs also demonstrate the promising potential of OHP-QDs for low-cost display, lighting, and optical communication applications.

Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites have the potential to be used as a new class of emitters with tunable emission, high color purity and good ease of fabrication. Recent studies have so far been focused on three-dimensional (3D) perovskites, such as CH3NH3PbBr3 and CH3NH3PbI3 for green and IR emission. Here, we explore a new series of hybrid perovskite emitters with a general formula of (C4H9NH3)2(CH3NH3)n-1PbnI3n+1 (where n = 1, 2, 3), which possesses a multiple quantum well structure. The quantum well thickness of these materials is adjustable through simple mol. engineering which results in a continuously tunable bandgap and emission spectra. Deep satd. red emission was obtained with a peak external quantum efficiency of 2.29% and a max. luminance of 214 cd/m2. Green and blue LEDs were also demonstrated through halogen substitutions in these hybrid perovskites. We expect these results to open up the way towards high performance perovskite LEDs through mol.-structure engineering of these perovskite emitters.

Perovskite energy funnels for efficient light-emitting diodes
Yuan, Mingjian; Quan, Li Na; Comin, Riccardo; Walters, Grant; Sabatini, Randy; Voznyy, Oleksandr; Hoogland, Sjoerd; Zhao, Yongbiao; Beauregard, Eric M.; Kanjanaboos, Pongsakorn; Lu, Zhenghong; Kim, Dong Ha; Sargent, Edward H.
Nature Nanotechnology
(
2016
),
11
(
10
),
872-877
CODEN:
NNAABX
; ISSN:
1748-3387
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
Organometal halide perovskites exhibit large bulk crystal domain sizes, rare traps, excellent mobilities and carriers that are free at room temp.-properties that support their excellent performance in charge-sepg. devices. In devices that rely on the forward injection of electrons and holes, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), excellent mobilities contribute to the efficient capture of non-equil. charge carriers by rare non-radiative centers. Moreover, the lack of bound excitons weakens the competition of desired radiative (over undesired non-radiative) recombination. Here we report a perovskite mixed material comprising a series of differently quantum-size-tuned grains that funnels photoexcitations to the lowest-bandgap light-emitter in the mixt. The materials function as charge carrier concentrators, ensuring that radiative recombination successfully out-competes trapping and hence non-radiative recombination. We use the new material to build devices that exhibit an external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 8.8% and a radiance of 80 W sr-1 m-2. These represent the brightest and most efficient soln.-processed near-IR LEDs to date.

Exciton Binding Energy and the Nature of Emissive States in Organometal Halide Perovskites
Zheng, Kaibo; Zhu, Qiushi; Abdellah, Mohamed; Messing, Maria E.; Zhang, Wei; Generalov, Alexander; Niu, Yuran; Ribaud, Lynn; Canton, Sophie E.; Pullerits, Tonu
Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters

(

CODEN:

; ISSN:
1948-7185
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Characteristics of nanoscale materials are often different from the corresponding bulk properties providing new, sometimes unexpected, opportunities for applications. Here the authors study the properties of 8 nm colloidal nanoparticles of MAPbBr3 perovskites and contrast them to the ones of large microcrystallites representing a bulk. X-ray spectroscopies provide an exciton binding energy of 0.32 ± 0.10 eV in the nanoparticles. This is 5 times higher than the value of bulk crystals (0.084 ± 0.010 eV), and readily explains the high fluorescence quantum yield in nanoparticles. In the bulk, at high excitation concns., the fluorescence intensity has quadratic behavior following the Saha-Langmuir model due to the nongeminate recombination of charges forming the emissive exciton states. In the nanoparticles, a linear dependence is obsd. since the excitation concn. per particle is significantly less than one. Even the bulk shows linear emission intensity dependence at lower excitation concns. In this case, the av. excitation spacing becomes larger than the carrier diffusion length suppressing the nongeminate recombination. From these considerations the authors obtain the charge carrier diffusion length in MAPbBr3 of 100 nm.

Overcoming the electroluminescence efficiency limitations of perovskite light-emitting diodes

Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites are emerging low-cost emitters with very high color purity, but their low luminescent efficiency is a crit. drawback. We boosted the current efficiency (CE) of perovskite light-emitting diodes with a simple bilayer structure to 42.9 candela per A, similar to the CE of phosphorescent org. light-emitting diodes OLED , with two modifications: We prevented the formation of metallic lead (Pb) atoms that cause strong exciton quenching through a small increase in methylammonium bromide (MABr) molar proportion, and we spatially confined the exciton in uniform MAPbBr3 nanograins (av. diam. = 99.7 nm) formed by a nanocrystal pinning process and concomitant redn. of exciton diffusion length to 67 nm. These changes caused substantial increases in steady-state photoluminescence intensity and efficiency of MAPbBr3 nanograin layers.

Laser Crystallization of Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Perovskite Solar Cells
Jeon, Taewoo; Jin, Hyeong Min; Lee, Seung Hyun; Lee, Ju Min; Park, Hyung Il; Kim, Mi Kyung; Lee, Keon Jae; Shin, Byungha; Kim, Sang Ouk

Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites attract enormous research interest for next generation solar energy harvest. Synergistic cryst. structures comprising org. and inorg. components enable soln. processing of perovskite films. A reliable crystn. method for perovskites, compatible with fast continuous process over large-area flexible substrates, is crucial for high performance solar cell prodn. Here, laser crystn. is presented of hybrid perovskite solar cells using near-IR (NIR) laser (λ = 1064 nm). Cryst. morphol. of CH3NH3PbI3 (MAPbI3) perovskite films are widely controllable with laser irradn. condition while maintaining film uniformity. Photothermal heating effectively assisted by interfacial photoconversion layers is crit. for phase transformation without beam damage of multilayered device structures. Notably, laser crystn. attains higher device performances than conventional thermal annealing. Fast laser crystn. with manuf. level scan rate (1 m min-1) demonstrates inverted-type perovskite solar cells with 11.3 and 8.0% efficiencies on typical glass and flexible polymer substrates, resp., without rigorous device optimization.

Jin, Hyeong Min; Lee, Seung Hyun; Kim, Ju Young; Son, Seung-Woo; Kim, Bong Hoon; Lee, Hwan Keon; Mun, Jeong Ho; Cha, Seung Keun; Kim, Jun Soo; Nealey, Paul F.; Lee, Keon Jae; Kim, Sang Ouk

Recent advance of high-power laser processing allows for rapid, continuous, area-selective material fabrication, typically represented by laser crystn. of silicon or oxides for display applications. Two-dimensional materials such as graphene exhibit remarkable phys. properties and are under intensive development for the manuf. of flexible devices. Here we demonstrate an area-selective ultrafast nanofabrication method using low intensity IR or visible laser irradn. to direct the self-assembly of block copolymer films into highly ordered manufg.-relevant architectures at the scale below 12 nm. The fundamental principles underlying this light-induced nanofabrication mechanism include the self-assembly of block copolymers to proceed across the disorder-order transition under large thermal gradients, and the use of chem. modified graphene films as a flexible and conformal light-absorbing layers for transparent, nonplanar, and mech. flexible surfaces.

The Role of Trap-assisted Recombination in Luminescent Properties of Organometal Halide CH3NH3PbBr3 Perovskite Films and Quantum Dots
Zhang, Zhen-Yu; Wang, Hai-Yu; Zhang, Yan-Xia; Hao, Ya-Wei; Sun, Chun; Zhang, Yu; Gao, Bing-Rong; Chen, Qi-Dai; Sun, Hong-Bo
Scientific Reports
(
2016
),
6
(
),
27286
CODEN:
SRCEC3
; ISSN:
2045-2322
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
Hybrid metal halide perovskites have been paid enormous attentions in photophysics research, whose excellent performances were attributed to their intriguing charge carriers proprieties. However, it still remains far from satisfaction in the comprehensive understanding of perovskite charge-transport properties, esp. about trap-assisted recombination process. In this Letter, through time-resolved transient absorption (TA) and photoluminescence (PL) measurements, we provided a relative comprehensive investigation on the charge carriers recombination dynamics of CH3NH3PbBr3 (MAPbBr3) perovskite films and quantum dots (QDs), esp. about trap-assisted recombination. It was found that the integral recombination mode of MAPbBr3 films was highly sensitive to the d. distribution of generated charge carriers and trap states. Addnl., Trap effects would be gradually weakened with elevated carrier densities. Furthermore, the trap-assisted recombination can be removed from MAPbBr3 QDs through its own surface passivation mechanism and this specialty may render the QDs as a new material in illuminating research. This work provides deeper phys. insights into the dynamics processes of MAPbBr3 materials and paves a way toward more light-harvesting applications in future.

Color-Pure Violet-Light-Emitting Diodes Based on Layered Lead Halide Perovskite Nanoplates
Liang, Dong; Peng, Yuelin; Fu, Yongping; Shearer, Melinda J.; Zhang, Jingjing; Zhai, Jianyuan; Zhang, Yi; Hamers, Robert J.; Andrew, Trisha L.; Jin, Song
ACS Nano

.

American Chemical Society

Violet electroluminescence is rare in both inorg. and org. LEDs. Low-cost and room-temp. soln.-processed Pb halide perovskites with high-efficiency and color-tunable luminescence are promising for LEDs. Room-temp. color-pure violet LEDs based on a 2-dimensional lead halide perovskite material, namely, 2-phenylethylammonium (C6H5CH2CH2NH3+, PEA) lead bromide [(PEA)2PbBr4] are reported. The natural quantum confinement of 2-dimensional layered perovskite (PEA)2PbBr4 allows for luminescence of shorter wavelength (410 nm) than its 3-dimensional counterpart. By converting as-deposited polycryst. thin films to micrometer-sized (PEA)2PbBr4 nanoplates using solvent vapor annealing, the authors successfully integrated this layered perovskite material into LEDs and achieved efficient room-temp. violet electroluminescence at 410 nm with a narrow bandwidth. This conversion to nanoplates significantly enhanced the crystallinity and photophys. properties of the (PEA)2PbBr4 samples and the external quantum efficiency of the violet LED. The solvent vapor annealing method reported herein can be generally applied to other perovskite materials to increase their grain size and, ultimately, improve the performance of optoelectronic devices based on perovskite materials.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Schematic illustration of the laser-crystallization process. There is no difference between before and after laser crystallization except the grain size and morphology. (b) SEM images of the MAPbBr
3
film morphology controlled by laser power density (fixed scan rate: 0.1 mm s
–1
). The MAPbBr
3
precursor layer is exposed to laser beam with various power densities from 20 to 50 W cm
–2
. The tendency of the grain size is scaled with increased power density. However, a discrete cuboid grain and discontinuous morphology appeared in 20 W cm
–2
condition. (c) Cross-sectional SEM images of laser-crystallized MAPbBr
3
with irradiated laser power density. As the power density increases, grain tends to be a well-defined increased grain size while maintaining the film thickness (about 200 nm) and morphology. In addition, 50 W cm
–2
power density induces nonuniformity of the MAPbBr
3
thin film.

Figure 2. SEM images of the MAPbBr
3
morphology of the grain growth procedure during laser irradiation controlled by irradiation conditions (scale bar: 500 nm). The inset figures show sequence of a grain boundary formation from (a) morphology quenching to perovskite particles, (b) aggregation of particles, and then (c, d) the grain and grain boundary growth. Final (e) grain size distribution is determined by total thermal energy, that is, power density of laser beam.

Figure 3. Optoelectronic characteristics of PeLEDs. (a) Statistical data of current efficiencies with coincidence laser power density. (b) Current density, (c) luminance, and (d) current efficiency of PeLED based on the laser-crystallization processed MAPbBr
3
layer with various laser irradiation conditions (fixed scan rate: 0.1 mm s
–1
).

Figure 4. (a) Fitting analysis of perovskite LEDs’ current efficiency and MAPbBr
3
perovskite grain size. (b) Correlation curve of MAPbBr
3
perovskite grain size distribution with power density. Current efficiency of PeLED strongly depends on perovskite grain size distribution. The perovskite LED which has a smaller grain size shows higher current efficiency. (c) XRD spectrum exhibit clearly peaks that can be assigned to (100), (110), (200), (210), (211), (220), and (300) planes, respectively. There is no difference of characteristics XRD peak position of MAPbBr
3
perovskite films with irradiated laser power density (scan rate, 0.1 mm s
–1
). (d) UV–visible spectrum of MAPbBr
3
with irradiated laser power density at constant scan rate, 0.1 mm s
–1
. UV absorption peak and photoluminescence peak are matched at 531 nm. There are no compositional changes by laser power even 50 W cm
–2
.

Figure 5. (a) PL measurement data of perovskite films with different laser irradiation conditions. Each film was irradiated with different laser powers with 0.1 mm s
–1
scan rate. The PL data showed similar tendency with maximum current efficiency of LED devices. (b) TRPL measurement of each perovskite film with different laser irradiation conditions. Each film shows biexponential decay curve. The shorter component is originated from nonradiative recombination, and the longer component is originated from radiative recombination. From this data, 30 W cm
–2
laser irradiation with 0.1 mm s
–1
scan rate showed the fastest radiative recombination, which showed the same tendency of current efficiency data.

Crystal organometal halide perovskites with promising optoelectronic applications
Chen, Junnian; Zhou, Shasha; Jin, Shengye; Li, Huiqiao; Zhai, Tianyou
Journal of Materials Chemistry C: Materials for Optical and Electronic Devices
(
2016
),
4
(
1
),

CODEN:

; ISSN:
2050-7534
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. Organometal halide perovskites AMX3 (A = org. cation, M = metal cation, and X = halogen anion) were dominating the photovoltaic fields with an unexpected sharp efficiency enhancement to 20.1% in the past 5 years. The extraordinary properties of optical absorption, luminescence and low nonradiative recombination rates extend their applications into optoelectronic fields beyond photovoltaic devices. This article briefly outlines the state-of-the-art research activities of crystal perovskite AMX3, describes the fundamental optoelectronic properties, specific morphols. and related synthesis techniques, and summarizes their functions in optoelectronic fields such as solar cells, lasers, light-emitting diodes and photodetectors. The general challenges and the potential future directions of this exciting research area are highlighted.

Veldhuis, Sjoerd A.; Boix, Pablo P.; Yantara, Natalia; Li, Mingjie; Sum, Tze Chien; Mathews, Nripan; Mhaisalkar, Subodh G.
Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany)

Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites have cemented their position as an exceptional class of optoelectronic materials thanks to record photovoltaic efficiencies of 22.1%, as well as promising demonstrations of light-emitting diodes, lasers, and light-emitting transistors. Perovskite materials with photoluminescence quantum yields close to 100% and perovskite light-emitting diodes with external quantum efficiencies of 8% and current efficiencies of 43 cd A-1 have been achieved. Although perovskite light-emitting devices are yet to become industrially relevant, in merely two years these devices have achieved the brightness and efficiencies that org. light-emitting diodes accomplished in two decades. Further advances will rely decisively on the multitude of compositional, structural variants that enable the formation of lower-dimensionality layered and three-dimensional perovskites, nanostructures, charge-transport materials, and device processing with architectural innovations. Here, the rapid advancements in perovskite light-emitting devices and lasers are reviewed. The key challenges in materials development, device fabrication, operational stability are addressed, and an outlook is presented that will address market viability of perovskite light-emitting devices.

Organometal halide perovskites are promising photo-absorption materials in solar cells due to their high extinction coeff., broad light absorption range and excellent semiconducting properties. The highest power conversion efficiency (PCE) of perovskite solar cells (PrSCs) is now 20.1%. However, a high-temp. processed mesoscopic metal oxide (e.g., TiO2) must be removed to realize flexible PrSCs on plastic substrates using low temp. processes. Although the planar heterojunction (PHJ) structure can be considered as the most appropriate structure for flexible PrSCs, they have shown lower PCEs than those with a mesoscopic metal oxide layer. Therefore, development of interfacial layers is essential for achieving highly efficient PHJ PrSCs, and necessary in fabrication of flexible PrSCs. This review article gives an overview of progress in PHJ PrSCs and the roles of interfacial layers in the device, and suggests a practical strategy to fabricate highly efficient and flexible PHJ PrSCs. We conclude with our tech. suggestion and outlook for further research direction.

This work proposes a new perovskite solar cell structure by including lithium-neutralized graphene oxide (GO-Li) as the electron transporting layer (ETL) on top of the mesoporous TiO2 (m-TiO2) substrate. The modified work-function of GO after the intercalation of Li atoms (4.3 eV) exhibits a good energy matching with the TiO2 conduction band, leading to a significant enhancement of the electron injection from the perovskite to the m-TiO2. The resulting devices exhibit an improved short circuit current and fill factor and a reduced hysteresis. Furthermore, the GO-Li ETL partially passivates the oxygen vacancies/defects of m-TiO2 by resulting in an enhanced stability under prolonged 1 SUN irradn.

Interfaces between perovskite solar cell (PSC) layer components play a pivotal role in obtaining high-performance premium cells and large-area modules. Graphene and related two-dimensional materials (GRMs) can be used to "on-demand" tune the interface properties of PSCs. We successfully used GRMs to realize large-area (active area 50.6 cm2) perovskite-based solar modules (PSMs), achieving a record high power conversion efficiency of 12.6%. We on-demand modulated the photoelectrode charge dynamic by doping the mesoporous TiO2 (mTiO2) layer with graphene flakes. Moreover, we exploited lithium-neutralized graphene oxide flakes as interlayer at the mTiO2/perovskite interface to improve charge injection. Notably, prolonged aging tests have shown the long-term stability for both small- and large-area devices using graphene-doped mTiO2. Furthermore, the possibility of producing and processing GRMs in the form of inks opens a promising route for further scale-up and stabilization of the PSM, the gateway for the commercialization of this technol.

A review. Org.-inorg. lead halide based perovskite solar cells are considered as one of the most promising 3rd generation photovoltaic technologies, since within a few years of focused research efforts, they have already presented certified efficiencies surpassing 22%. The high performance, together with the low fabrication cost, makes this technol. competitive with state-of-the-art thin film photovoltaics (CdTe and CIGS). However perovskite solar cells present some striking disadvantages hindering their commercialization, including a lower performance compared to com. available Si based photovoltaics (26.6%), a low stability tolerance under high levels of moisture and temp., lead B-cation toxicity and the hysteresis effect which ruins both the performance and long term stability of the devices. Recently, a promising approach to tackle the aforementioned disadvantages was the introduction of plasmonic metal and rare-earth-element upconversion nanoparticles in the building blocks of the devices. The authors review the theor. and exptl. results of the literature regarding the introduction of different constitution, size, shape and coating plasmonic metal and rare-earth-element upconversion nanoparticles into the building blocks of both planar and mesoscopic perovskite solar cells. The authors analyze their effect on the device performance, stability, hysteresis effect and how they can be very beneficial for making these solar cells environmentally friendly and compatible with tandem applications. The crit. challenges and the prospects of this newly developed field and propose some prospects for future research directions are discussed.

Bright light-emitting diodes based on organometal halide perovskite
Tan, Zhi-Kuang; Moghaddam, Reza Saberi; Lai, May Ling; Docampo, Pablo; Higler, Ruben; Deschler, Felix; Price, Michael; Sadhanala, Aditya; Pazos, Luis M.; Credgington, Dan; Hanusch, Fabian; Bein, Thomas; Snaith, Henry J.; Friend, Richard H.

Solid-state light-emitting devices based on direct-bandgap semiconductors have, over the past two decades, been utilized as energy-efficient sources of lighting. However, fabrication of these devices typically relies on expensive high-temp. and high-vacuum processes, rendering them uneconomical for use in large-area displays. Here, we report high-brightness light-emitting diodes based on soln.-processed organometal halide perovskites. We demonstrate electroluminescence in the near-IR, green and red by tuning the halide compns. in the perovskite. In our IR device, a thin 15 nm layer of CH3NH3PbI3-xClx perovskite emitter is sandwiched between larger-bandgap titanium dioxide (TiO2) and poly(9,9'-dioctylfluorene) (F8) layers, effectively confining electrons and holes in the perovskite layer for radiative recombination. We report an IR radiance of 13.2 W sr-1 m-2 at a c.d. of 363 mA cm-2, with highest external and internal quantum efficiencies of 0.76% and 3.4%, resp. In our green light-emitting device with an ITO/PEDOT:PSS/CH3NH3PbBr3/F8/Ca/Ag structure, we achieved a luminance of 364 cd m-2 at a c.d. of 123 mA cm-2, giving external and internal quantum efficiencies of 0.1% and 0.4%, resp. We show, using photoluminescence studies, that radiative bimol. recombination is dominant at higher excitation densities. Hence, the quantum efficiencies of the perovskite light-emitting diodes increase at higher current densities. This demonstration of effective perovskite electroluminescence offers scope for developing this unique class of materials into efficient and color-tunable light emitters for low-cost display, lighting and optical communication applications.

Electroluminescence in light-emitting devices relies on the encounter and radiative recombination of electrons and holes in the emissive layer. In organometal halide perovskite light-emitting diodes, poor film formation creates elec. shunting paths, where injected charge carriers bypass the perovskite emitter, leading to a loss in electroluminescence yield. Here, the authors report a soln.-processing method to block elec. shunts and thereby enhance electroluminescence quantum efficiency in perovskite devices. In this method, a blend of perovskite and a polyimide precursor dielec. (PIP) is soln.-deposited to form perovskite nanocrystals in a thin-film matrix of PIP. The PIP forms a pinhole-free charge-blocking layer, while still allowing the embedded perovskite crystals to form elec. contact with the electron- and hole-injection layers. This modified structure reduces nonradiative current losses and improves quantum efficiency by 2 orders of magnitude, giving an external quantum efficiency of 1.2%. This simple technique provides an alternative route to circumvent film formation problems in perovskite optoelectronics and offers the possibility of flexible and high-performance light-emitting displays.

Soln.-processable perovskite materials have garnered tremendous attention because of their excellent charge carrier mobility, possibility of a tunable optical bandgap, and high photoluminescence quantum efficiency (PLQE). In particular, the uniform morphol. of a perovskite film is the most important factor in realizing perovskite light-emitting diodes (PeLEDs) with high efficiency and full-coverage electroluminescence (EL). In this study, we demonstrate highly efficient PeLEDs that contain a perovskite film with a uniform morphol. by introducing HBr into the perovskite precursor. The introduction of HBr into the perovskite precursor results in a perovskite film with a uniform, continuous morphol. because the HBr increases the soly. of the inorg. component in the perovskite precursor and reduces the crystn. rate of the perovskite film upon spin-coating. Moreover, PeLEDs fabricated using perovskite films with a uniform, continuous morphol., which were deposited using 6 vol% HBr in a DMF (DMF)/hydrobromic acid (HBr) cosolvent, exhibited full coverage of the green EL emission. Finally, the optimized PeLEDs fabricated with perovskite films deposited using the DMF/HBr cosolvent exhibited a max. luminance of 3490 cd m-2 (at 4.3 V) and a luminous efficiency of 0.43 cd A-1 (at 4.3 V).

A facile synthetic method to produce highly emissive MeNH3+PbBr3- nanoplatelets with bright, stable, and spectrally narrow emission is presented. Compared to polycryst. bulk perovskites, the nanoplatelets have significantly higher PL quantum yield that allows for the fabrication of bright elec. driven PeLEDs. The high stability and moisture resistance of these org. ligand-capped perovskites nanoplatelets enables glove box-free device fabrication. The integration of bipolar PVK:PBD layer with the soln.-processable perovskite nanoplatelets layer improved the film morphol., as well as charge transport and recombination, resulting in 1 of the brightest perovskite LEDs reported to date. The work demonstrates a new pathway toward optoelectronic devices based on soln.-processable materials and further shows the promises of nanoscale org.-inorg. halide perovskites as a new class of semiconductors with desirable characteristics for optoelectronic devices. The demonstrated emitter/bipolar host structure can be extended, to other perovskite nanostructures as light emitter for optoelectronic. devices, and finally achieve the white light PeLED by using the mixt. of perovskite with different emission wavelengths.

Due to sparse concns. and difficulties in the enrichment of OHP-QDs, prodn. of large-area uniform films of OHP-QDs is a challenging task, which largely impedes their use in electroluminescence devices. Here, a simple dip-coating method has been reported to effectively fabricate large-area uniform films of OHP-QDs. Using this technique, multicolor OHP-QDs light-emitting diodes (OQ-LEDs) emitting in blue, blue-green, green, orange, and red color have been successfully produced by simply tuning the halide compn. or size of QDs. The blue, green, and red OQ-LEDs exhibited, resp., a max. luminance of 2673, 2398, and 986 cd m-2 at a current efficiency of 4.01, 3.72, and 1.52 cd A-1, and an external quantum efficiency of 1.38%, 1.06%, and 0.53%, which are much better than most LEDs based on OHP films. The packaged OQ-LEDs show long-term stability in air (humidity ≈50%) for at least 7 d. The results demonstrate the great potential of the dip-coating method to fabricate large-area uniform films for various QDs. The high-efficiency OQ-LEDs also demonstrate the promising potential of OHP-QDs for low-cost display, lighting, and optical communication applications.

span.span: Molecularly Engineered Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Perovskite with Multiple Quantum Well Structure for Multicolored Light-Emitting Diodes

Molecularly Engineered Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Perovskite with Multiple Quantum Well Structure for Multicolored Light-Emitting Diodes
Hu, Hongwei; Salim, Teddy; Chen, Bingbing; Lam, Yeng Ming
Scientific Reports
(

),
6
(

33546
CODEN:

; ISSN:

Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites have the potential to be used as a new class of emitters with tunable emission, high color purity and good ease of fabrication. Recent studies have so far been focused on three-dimensional (3D) perovskites, such as CH3NH3PbBr3 and CH3NH3PbI3 for green and IR emission. Here, we explore a new series of hybrid perovskite emitters with a general formula of (C4H9NH3)2(CH3NH3)n-1PbnI3n+1 (where n = 1, 2, 3), which possesses a multiple quantum well structure. The quantum well thickness of these materials is adjustable through simple mol. engineering which results in a continuously tunable bandgap and emission spectra. Deep satd. red emission was obtained with a peak external quantum efficiency of 2.29% and a max. luminance of 214 cd/m2. Green and blue LEDs were also demonstrated through halogen substitutions in these hybrid perovskites. We expect these results to open up the way towards high performance perovskite LEDs through mol.-structure engineering of these perovskite emitters.

Perovskite energy funnels for efficient light-emitting diodes
Yuan, Mingjian; Quan, Li Na; Comin, Riccardo; Walters, Grant; Sabatini, Randy; Voznyy, Oleksandr; Hoogland, Sjoerd; Zhao, Yongbiao; Beauregard, Eric M.; Kanjanaboos, Pongsakorn; Lu, Zhenghong; Kim, Dong Ha; Sargent, Edward H.
Nature Nanotechnology
(
2016
),
11
(
10
),
872-877
CODEN:
NNAABX
; ISSN:
1748-3387
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
Organometal halide perovskites exhibit large bulk crystal domain sizes, rare traps, excellent mobilities and carriers that are free at room temp.-properties that support their excellent performance in charge-sepg. devices. In devices that rely on the forward injection of electrons and holes, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), excellent mobilities contribute to the efficient capture of non-equil. charge carriers by rare non-radiative centers. Moreover, the lack of bound excitons weakens the competition of desired radiative (over undesired non-radiative) recombination. Here we report a perovskite mixed material comprising a series of differently quantum-size-tuned grains that funnels photoexcitations to the lowest-bandgap light-emitter in the mixt. The materials function as charge carrier concentrators, ensuring that radiative recombination successfully out-competes trapping and hence non-radiative recombination. We use the new material to build devices that exhibit an external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 8.8% and a radiance of 80 W sr-1 m-2. These represent the brightest and most efficient soln.-processed near-IR LEDs to date.

Exciton Binding Energy and the Nature of Emissive States in Organometal Halide Perovskites
Zheng, Kaibo; Zhu, Qiushi; Abdellah, Mohamed; Messing, Maria E.; Zhang, Wei; Generalov, Alexander; Niu, Yuran; Ribaud, Lynn; Canton, Sophie E.; Pullerits, Tonu
Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters

.

)
Characteristics of nanoscale materials are often different from the corresponding bulk properties providing new, sometimes unexpected, opportunities for applications. Here the authors study the properties of 8 nm colloidal nanoparticles of MAPbBr3 perovskites and contrast them to the ones of large microcrystallites representing a bulk. X-ray spectroscopies provide an exciton binding energy of 0.32 ± 0.10 eV in the nanoparticles. This is 5 times higher than the value of bulk crystals (0.084 ± 0.010 eV), and readily explains the high fluorescence quantum yield in nanoparticles. In the bulk, at high excitation concns., the fluorescence intensity has quadratic behavior following the Saha-Langmuir model due to the nongeminate recombination of charges forming the emissive exciton states. In the nanoparticles, a linear dependence is obsd. since the excitation concn. per particle is significantly less than one. Even the bulk shows linear emission intensity dependence at lower excitation concns. In this case, the av. excitation spacing becomes larger than the carrier diffusion length suppressing the nongeminate recombination. From these considerations the authors obtain the charge carrier diffusion length in MAPbBr3 of 100 nm.

Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites are emerging low-cost emitters with very high color purity, but their low luminescent efficiency is a crit. drawback. We boosted the current efficiency (CE) of perovskite light-emitting diodes with a simple bilayer structure to 42.9 candela per A, similar to the CE of phosphorescent org. light-emitting diodes OLED , with two modifications: We prevented the formation of metallic lead (Pb) atoms that cause strong exciton quenching through a small increase in methylammonium bromide (MABr) molar proportion, and we spatially confined the exciton in uniform MAPbBr3 nanograins (av. diam. = 99.7 nm) formed by a nanocrystal pinning process and concomitant redn. of exciton diffusion length to 67 nm. These changes caused substantial increases in steady-state photoluminescence intensity and efficiency of MAPbBr3 nanograin layers.

Laser Crystallization of Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Perovskite Solar Cells
Jeon, Taewoo; Jin, Hyeong Min; Lee, Seung Hyun; Lee, Ju Min; Park, Hyung Il; Kim, Mi Kyung; Lee, Keon Jae; Shin, Byungha; Kim, Sang Ouk

Org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites attract enormous research interest for next generation solar energy harvest. Synergistic cryst. structures comprising org. and inorg. components enable soln. processing of perovskite films. A reliable crystn. method for perovskites, compatible with fast continuous process over large-area flexible substrates, is crucial for high performance solar cell prodn. Here, laser crystn. is presented of hybrid perovskite solar cells using near-IR (NIR) laser (λ = 1064 nm). Cryst. morphol. of CH3NH3PbI3 (MAPbI3) perovskite films are widely controllable with laser irradn. condition while maintaining film uniformity. Photothermal heating effectively assisted by interfacial photoconversion layers is crit. for phase transformation without beam damage of multilayered device structures. Notably, laser crystn. attains higher device performances than conventional thermal annealing. Fast laser crystn. with manuf. level scan rate (1 m min-1) demonstrates inverted-type perovskite solar cells with 11.3 and 8.0% efficiencies on typical glass and flexible polymer substrates, resp., without rigorous device optimization.

Jin, Hyeong Min; Lee, Seung Hyun; Kim, Ju Young; Son, Seung-Woo; Kim, Bong Hoon; Lee, Hwan Keon; Mun, Jeong Ho; Cha, Seung Keun; Kim, Jun Soo; Nealey, Paul F.; Lee, Keon Jae; Kim, Sang Ouk

Recent advance of high-power laser processing allows for rapid, continuous, area-selective material fabrication, typically represented by laser crystn. of silicon or oxides for display applications. Two-dimensional materials such as graphene exhibit remarkable phys. properties and are under intensive development for the manuf. of flexible devices. Here we demonstrate an area-selective ultrafast nanofabrication method using low intensity IR or visible laser irradn. to direct the self-assembly of block copolymer films into highly ordered manufg.-relevant architectures at the scale below 12 nm. The fundamental principles underlying this light-induced nanofabrication mechanism include the self-assembly of block copolymers to proceed across the disorder-order transition under large thermal gradients, and the use of chem. modified graphene films as a flexible and conformal light-absorbing layers for transparent, nonplanar, and mech. flexible surfaces.

The Role of Trap-assisted Recombination in Luminescent Properties of Organometal Halide CH3NH3PbBr3 Perovskite Films and Quantum Dots
Zhang, Zhen-Yu; Wang, Hai-Yu; Zhang, Yan-Xia; Hao, Ya-Wei; Sun, Chun; Zhang, Yu; Gao, Bing-Rong; Chen, Qi-Dai; Sun, Hong-Bo
Scientific Reports

Nature Publishing Group

Hybrid metal halide perovskites have been paid enormous attentions in photophysics research, whose excellent performances were attributed to their intriguing charge carriers proprieties. However, it still remains far from satisfaction in the comprehensive understanding of perovskite charge-transport properties, esp. about trap-assisted recombination process. In this Letter, through time-resolved transient absorption (TA) and photoluminescence (PL) measurements, we provided a relative comprehensive investigation on the charge carriers recombination dynamics of CH3NH3PbBr3 (MAPbBr3) perovskite films and quantum dots (QDs), esp. about trap-assisted recombination. It was found that the integral recombination mode of MAPbBr3 films was highly sensitive to the d. distribution of generated charge carriers and trap states. Addnl., Trap effects would be gradually weakened with elevated carrier densities. Furthermore, the trap-assisted recombination can be removed from MAPbBr3 QDs through its own surface passivation mechanism and this specialty may render the QDs as a new material in illuminating research. This work provides deeper phys. insights into the dynamics processes of MAPbBr3 materials and paves a way toward more light-harvesting applications in future.

Color-Pure Violet-Light-Emitting Diodes Based on Layered Lead Halide Perovskite Nanoplates
Liang, Dong; Peng, Yuelin; Fu, Yongping; Shearer, Melinda J.; Zhang, Jingjing; Zhai, Jianyuan; Zhang, Yi; Hamers, Robert J.; Andrew, Trisha L.; Jin, Song
ACS Nano

Violet electroluminescence is rare in both inorg. and org. LEDs. Low-cost and room-temp. soln.-processed Pb halide perovskites with high-efficiency and color-tunable luminescence are promising for LEDs. Room-temp. color-pure violet LEDs based on a 2-dimensional lead halide perovskite material, namely, 2-phenylethylammonium (C6H5CH2CH2NH3+, PEA) lead bromide [(PEA)2PbBr4] are reported. The natural quantum confinement of 2-dimensional layered perovskite (PEA)2PbBr4 allows for luminescence of shorter wavelength (410 nm) than its 3-dimensional counterpart. By converting as-deposited polycryst. thin films to micrometer-sized (PEA)2PbBr4 nanoplates using solvent vapor annealing, the authors successfully integrated this layered perovskite material into LEDs and achieved efficient room-temp. violet electroluminescence at 410 nm with a narrow bandwidth. This conversion to nanoplates significantly enhanced the crystallinity and photophys. properties of the (PEA)2PbBr4 samples and the external quantum efficiency of the violet LED. The solvent vapor annealing method reported herein can be generally applied to other perovskite materials to increase their grain size and, ultimately, improve the performance of optoelectronic devices based on perovskite materials.
